unknown.description: This appears to be an unidentified plant issue. The symptoms are visible but require further analysis for proper identification. Consider consulting with a local agricultural expert or extension service for accurate diagnosis and treatment recommendations.
symptoms: Visible abnormal symptoms detected
May cause plant stress and reduced vigor
Could potentially spread to other plants
Unclear symptom pattern requiring professional assessment

organic.name: Neem oil spray
organic.safety: Safe for beneficial insects when applied in evening. Avoid spraying during peak sun hours.

organic.name: Baking soda solution
organic.safety: Test on small area first. May cause leaf burn in hot weather.

chemical.name: Copper-based fungicide
chemical.safety: Wear protective equipment. Avoid spraying during bloom period.

preventive: Monitor plant regularly for symptom changes
Maintain good air circulation around plants
Avoid overhead watering to reduce humidity
Remove affected plant parts immediately
Practice proper sanitation between plants
Ensure adequate plant spacing

early blight.description: Early blight is a common fungal disease that primarily affects solanaceous plants like tomatoes, potatoes, and eggplants. It causes characteristic dark spots with concentric rings on leaves, typically starting from the bottom of the plant and moving upward.
symptoms: Dark brown to black spots with concentric rings (target-like pattern)
Yellowing and premature dropping of older, lower leaves
Dark, sunken lesions on stems and branches
Leathery, dark spots on fruits with concentric rings
Reduced plant vigor and stunted growth

organic.name: Copper fungicide
organic.safety: Avoid spraying during bloom to protect pollinators. Apply in early morning or evening.

organic.name: Baking soda spray
organic.dosage: 1 tablespoon per gallon of water + 1/2 tsp liquid soap
organic.safety: Test on small area first. May cause leaf burn in temperatures above 85°F.

organic.name: Compost tea
organic.safety: Completely safe. Apply as foliar spray or soil drench.

chemical.name: Chlorothalonil
chemical.dosage: Follow label instructions (typically 1-2 tsp per quart)
chemical.safety: Wear full protective equipment. Avoid drift to water sources. Do not apply within 7 days of harvest.

chemical.name: Mancozeb
chemical.safety: Highly toxic. Use protective equipment. Pre-harvest interval varies by crop.

preventive: Space plants adequately for good air circulation
Water at soil level using drip irrigation or soaker hoses
Remove and destroy infected plant debris at end of season
Rotate crops annually (avoid solanaceous plants in same location)
Apply organic mulch to prevent soil splashing onto leaves
Choose resistant varieties when available
Maintain consistent soil moisture to reduce plant stress

late blight.description: Late blight is a devastating oomycete disease that can destroy entire tomato and potato crops within days under favorable conditions. This is the same disease that caused the Irish Potato Famine. It thrives in cool, wet conditions and spreads rapidly through airborne spores.
symptoms: Water-soaked, dark green to brown spots on leaves
White, fuzzy sporangial growth on undersides of leaves
Rapid expansion of lesions during humid conditions
Black, firm rot on fruits starting from the stem end
Brown to black lesions on stems and petioles
Complete plant collapse in severe cases
Distinctive musty odor from infected tissues

organic.name: Copper hydroxide
organic.frequency: Every 5-7 days during favorable disease conditions
organic.safety: Apply early morning or evening to reduce phytotoxicity. Copper can accumulate in soil over time.

organic.name: Potassium bicarbonate
organic.safety: Generally safe but may cause leaf burn on sensitive plants in hot weather.

chemical.name: Mancozeb + Copper
chemical.frequency: Every 7-10 days preventively, every 5-7 days if disease present
chemical.safety: Highly toxic. Full protective equipment required. Toxic to fish and aquatic life.

chemical.name: Chlorothalonil + Propamocarb
chemical.frequency: Alternate with other fungicides to prevent resistance
chemical.safety: Professional application recommended. Observe pre-harvest intervals.

preventive: Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes and transplants
Choose resistant or tolerant varieties when available
Ensure excellent drainage and avoid overhead irrigation
Monitor weather conditions - disease favors 60-70°F with high humidity
Remove all infected plant material immediately and destroy
Avoid working in fields when plants are wet
Apply preventive fungicide sprays before disease symptoms appear
Maintain wide plant spacing for air circulation
Remove volunteer potato plants and nightshade weeds

powdery mildew.description: Powdery mildew is a widespread fungal disease that affects many plant species. It appears as white, powdery patches on leaves and stems, thriving in warm, dry conditions with high humidity. Unlike many fungal diseases, it doesn't require water on leaf surfaces to germinate.
symptoms: White to gray powdery coating on leaf surfaces
Initial spots on upper leaf surfaces that expand and merge
Yellowing and curling of affected leaves
Stunted plant growth and reduced vigor
Premature leaf drop in severe infections
Reduced fruit quality and yield
Powdery growth may also appear on stems and flowers

organic.name: Milk spray
organic.safety: Completely safe for humans and beneficial insects. May attract beneficial microorganisms.

organic.name: Potassium bicarbonate
organic.dosage: 1 tablespoon per gallon + 1/2 tsp horticultural oil
organic.safety: Generally safe. Avoid application during hot, sunny conditions to prevent leaf burn.

organic.name: Sulfur dust or spray
organic.safety: Do not apply when temperatures exceed 85°F. Can be irritating to skin and eyes.

chemical.name: Myclobutanil
chemical.frequency: Every 14 days, rotate with other modes of action
chemical.safety: Toxic to fish and aquatic invertebrates. Avoid application before rain.

chemical.name: Propiconazole
chemical.safety: Wear protective equipment. Do not exceed maximum applications per season.

preventive: Plant resistant or tolerant varieties when available
Provide good air circulation through proper spacing
Avoid overhead watering; use drip irrigation
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization which promotes susceptible growth
Remove and destroy infected leaves promptly
Clean up plant debris at end of growing season
Monitor humidity levels in greenhouse environments
Ensure adequate sunlight reaches plant canopy

aphids.description: Aphids are small, soft-bodied insects that feed on plant sap by inserting their needle-like mouthparts into plant tissues. They reproduce rapidly and can quickly establish large colonies. They also vector many plant viruses, making their control important beyond direct feeding damage.
symptoms: Small, soft-bodied insects clustered on new growth and leaf undersides
Sticky honeydew secretions on leaves and surrounding surfaces
Curled, distorted, or yellowing leaves
Stunted plant growth and reduced vigor
Presence of ants farming aphids for honeydew
Sooty mold growing on honeydew deposits
Transmission of viral diseases between plants

organic.name: Insecticidal soap
organic.safety: Safe for beneficial insects once dry. Test on small area first for sensitive plants.

organic.name: Neem oil
organic.safety: Apply in evening to protect pollinators. May cause phytotoxicity on some plants in hot weather.

organic.name: Ladybug release
organic.frequency: One-time release when aphids first appear
organic.safety: Completely safe biological control. Pre-chill beetles and release in evening.

chemical.name: Imidacloprid (soil drench)
chemical.safety: Highly toxic to bees and other pollinators. Do not apply to flowering plants or when bees are active.

chemical.name: Pyrethrin spray
chemical.safety: Low toxicity to mammals. Highly toxic to fish. Apply in evening to reduce bee exposure.

preventive: Encourage beneficial insects with diverse plantings
Use reflective aluminum mulch to deter aphids
Monitor plants weekly, especially new growth
Remove weeds that serve as alternate hosts
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen which promotes succulent growth
Use row covers on young plants during peak aphid seasons
Plant trap crops like nasturtiums to attract aphids away from main crops
Maintain proper plant spacing for good air circulation

spider mites.description: Spider mites are tiny arachnids that feed on plant cells by piercing leaf tissues and sucking out contents. They thrive in hot, dry conditions and can rapidly build up populations. Their feeding causes stippling damage and they produce fine webbing on heavily infested plants.
symptoms: Fine silken webbing on leaves, stems, and growing tips
Yellow or bronze stippling on leaf surfaces
Leaves turning yellow, bronze, or brown
Tiny moving specks on undersides of leaves
Premature leaf drop and defoliation
Reduced plant vigor and growth
Dusty appearance on leaf surfaces

organic.name: Predatory mites (Phytoseiulus persimilis)
organic.frequency: One release when mites first detected
organic.safety: Completely safe biological control. Effective in greenhouse and outdoor conditions.

organic.name: Horticultural oil
organic.safety: Apply during cooler temperatures (below 85°F) to avoid plant damage. Test on small area first.

organic.name: Diatomaceous earth (food grade)
organic.safety: Safe for beneficial insects. Apply when no wind. Wear dust mask during application.

chemical.name: Bifenthrin
chemical.frequency: Every 7-14 days, maximum 4 applications per season
chemical.safety: Highly toxic to bees, fish, and aquatic invertebrates. Do not apply during bloom or near water sources.

chemical.name: Abamectin
chemical.safety: Moderately toxic. Avoid drift to non-target areas. Allow re-entry interval before harvesting.

preventive: Maintain adequate humidity levels (50-60%)
Avoid dusty conditions around plants
Regular forceful water spraying to dislodge mites
Remove heavily infested leaves promptly
Plant diverse crops to encourage natural predators
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
Use reflective mulches to reduce heat buildup
Monitor plants regularly, especially during hot, dry periods

bacterial spot.description: Bacterial spot is a serious disease affecting tomatoes and peppers. It causes lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits, and can result in significant yield losses. The bacteria spread through water splash, contaminated tools, and infected seeds.
symptoms: Small, dark brown to black spots on leaves with yellow halos
Leaf spots may merge causing large necrotic areas
Dark, raised lesions on fruits
Defoliation starting with older leaves
Stem cankers in severe infections
Reduced fruit quality and marketability

organic.name: Copper hydroxide
organic.safety: Apply during dry conditions. Copper can accumulate in soil over time.

organic.name: Streptomycin (where approved)
organic.safety: Use only as directed. Resistance can develop with overuse.

chemical.name: Copper + Mancozeb combination
chemical.safety: Full protective equipment required. Observe pre-harvest intervals.

preventive: Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants
Avoid overhead irrigation and work when plants are wet
Practice crop rotation with non-host plants
Remove and destroy infected plant debris
Disinfect tools between plants
Choose resistant varieties when available
Maintain proper plant spacing for air circulation

downy mildew.description: Downy mildew is an oomycete disease that affects many crops, particularly in cool, wet conditions. It appears as yellow patches on upper leaf surfaces with fuzzy growth underneath.
symptoms: Yellow patches on upper leaf surfaces
Fuzzy, grayish-white growth on undersides of leaves
Leaf distortion and curling
Premature leaf drop
Stunted plant growth
Reduced yield and quality

organic.name: Copper fungicide
organic.safety: Apply in dry conditions to reduce phytotoxicity.

organic.name: Bacillus subtilis
organic.safety: Completely safe biological fungicide.

chemical.name: Metalaxyl + Mancozeb
chemical.safety: Use protective equipment. Rotate modes of action.

preventive: Improve air circulation around plants
Avoid overhead watering
Remove infected plant material
Plant resistant varieties
Practice crop rotation
Monitor humidity levels in greenhouse

whiteflies.description: Whiteflies are small, flying insects that feed on plant sap and can transmit viral diseases. They are particularly problematic in warm climates and greenhouse environments.
symptoms: Small, white flying insects around plants
Sticky honeydew on leaves
Yellowing and wilting of leaves
Stunted plant growth
Sooty mold on honeydew
Virus transmission symptoms

organic.name: Yellow sticky traps
organic.safety: Completely safe physical control method.

organic.name: Insecticidal soap
organic.safety: Safe for beneficial insects when dry.

chemical.name: Imidacloprid
chemical.safety: Toxic to pollinators. Do not apply to flowering plants.

preventive: Use reflective mulches
Install fine mesh screens
Remove weedy hosts
Monitor regularly with sticky traps
Quarantine new plants
Maintain proper plant spacing

thrips.description: Thrips are tiny, slender insects that feed by rasping leaf surfaces and sucking plant juices. They can transmit tospoviruses and cause significant damage to young plants.
symptoms: Silver or bronze streaks on leaves
Black specks (thrips excrement) on leaves
Distorted or curled leaves
Scarring on fruits
Stunted plant growth
Virus symptoms if present

organic.name: Blue sticky traps
organic.safety: Safe physical control method.

organic.name: Predatory mites
organic.safety: Completely safe biological control.

chemical.name: Spinosad
chemical.safety: Low toxicity to mammals. Apply in evening to protect bees.

preventive: Remove weeds and plant debris
Use reflective mulches
Monitor with sticky traps
Quarantine new plants
Maintain proper humidity levels
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
